column4: What should you do before making a U-turn?
column6: Give an arm signal as well as using your indicators
column7: Check road markings to see that U-turns are permitted
column8: Look over your shoulder for a final check
column9: Select a higher gear than normal
column10: If you have to make a U-turn, slow down and make sure that the road is clear in both directions. Make sure that the road is wide enough for you to carry out the manoeuvre safely. Use your mirrors and look round to check it's safe before turning across the road.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility

25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
7/2/2025:  Ensure to make sure

column4: What should you do as you approach this bridge?
column10: You should slow down and be cautious. Hump bridges are often narrow and there may not be enough room for you to pass an oncoming vehicle at this point. Also, there's no footpath, so be aware of pedestrians in the road.
column11:
7/8/2015:  Amended made during the global change to 'Mark one answer'
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: Where should you avoid overtaking?
column9: Approaching a dip in the road
column10: Oncoming vehicles or other hazards can be hidden from view by dips in the road. If you cannot see into the dip, wait until you have a clear view and can see that it's safe before starting to overtake.
column11:

column4: What does this curved arrow road marking mean?
column6: Heavy vehicles should take the next road on the left to avoid a weight limit
column7: The road ahead bends to the left
column8: Overtaking traffic should move back to the left
column9: The road ahead has a camber to the left
column10: In this picture, the road marking shows that overtaking drivers or riders need to return to the left. These markings show the direction drivers must pass hatch markings or solid double white lines. They're also used to show the route that high vehicles should take under a low arched bridge.
column11:

column4: What should you do if your mobile phone rings while you're driving or riding?
column8: Leave it until you have stopped in a safe place
column9: Pull up at the nearest kerb
column10: It’s illegal to use a hand-held mobile or similar device when driving or riding, except in a genuine emergency. The safest option is to switch off your mobile phone before you set off, and use a message service. If you've forgotten to switch your phone off and it rings, you should leave it. When you've stopped in a safe place, you can see who called and return the call if necessary.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: Why are these yellow lines painted across the road?
column6: To help you choose the correct lane
column7: To help you keep the correct separation distance
column8: To make you aware of your speed
column9: To tell you the distance to the roundabout
column10: These lines are often found on the approach to a roundabout or a dangerous junction. They give you extra warning to adjust your speed. Look well ahead and do this in good time.
column11:
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
23/11/2023:  Updates to cross references after new KYTS

column4: What should you do when you're approaching traffic lights that have been green for some time?
column10: The longer traffic lights have been green, the sooner they'll change. Allow for this as you approach traffic lights that you know have been green for a while. They're likely to change soon, so you should be prepared to stop.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: What should you do before slowing down or stopping your vehicle?
column10: Before slowing down or stopping, check the mirrors to see what's happening behind you. Also assess what's ahead and make sure you give the correct signal if it will help other road users.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style and removal of 'of the following' in the stem
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: You're following a large vehicle. Why should you stay a safe distance behind it?
column6: You'll be able to corner more quickly
column7: You'll help the large vehicle to stop more easily
column8: You'll give the driver a chance to see you in their mirrors
column9: You'll keep out of the wind better
column10: If you're following a large vehicle but are so close to it that you cannot see its exterior mirrors, the driver will not be able to see you. Keeping well back will also allow you to see the road ahead by looking past the large vehicle.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contractions

column4: Why should you use your mirrors when you see a hazard ahead?
column6: Because you'll need to accelerate out of danger
column7: To assess how your actions will affect the traffic behind
column8: Because you'll need to brake sharply and stop
column9: To check what's happening on the road ahead
column10: You should be constantly scanning the road for clues about what's going to happen next. Check your mirrors regularly, particularly as soon as you spot a hazard. What's happening behind may affect how you respond to hazards ahead.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: You're waiting to turn right at the end of a road. What should you do if your view is obstructed by parked vehicles?
column6: Stop and then move forward slowly and carefully for a clear view
column7: Move quickly to where you can see so you only block traffic from one direction
column8: Wait for a pedestrian to let you know when it's safe for you to emerge
column9: Turn your vehicle around immediately and find another junction to use
column10: At junctions, your view is often restricted by buildings, trees or parked cars. You need to be able to see in order to judge a safe gap. Edge forward slowly and keep looking all the time. Do not cause other road users to change speed or direction as you emerge.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contraction

column4: There are objects hanging from your interior mirror. Why could this be a hazard?
column7: Your sun visor might get tangled
column8: Your radio reception might be affected
column9: Your windscreen could mist up more easily
column10: Make sure that you can see clearly through the windscreen of your vehicle. Stickers or hanging objects could obstruct your view or draw your attention away from the road.
column11:
5/8/2015:  5 August 2015 changed to Mark one answer
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility

column4: You're on a long motorway journey. What should you do if you start to feel sleepy?
column7: Stop on the hard shoulder for a rest
column8: Drive faster to complete your journey sooner
column9: Leave the motorway and stop in a safe place
column10: If you feel sleepy, you should leave the motorway at a service area or at the next exit and stop in a safe place to rest. A supply of fresh air can help to keep you alert before you reach the exit, but it’s not a substitute for stopping and resting.
column11:
5/8/2015:  5 August 2015 changed to Mark one answer
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contraction

column4: Why should you switch your headlights on when it first starts to get dark?
column6: To make your dials easier to see
column7: So others can see you more easily
column8: So that you blend in with other drivers
column9: Because the street lights are lit
column10: Your headlights and tail lights help others on the road to see you. It may be necessary to turn on your headlights during the day if visibility is reduced; for example, due to heavy rain. In these conditions, the light might fade before the street lights are timed to switch on. Be seen to be safe.
column11:
5/8/2015:  5 August 2015 changed to Mark one answer
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: What’s most likely to distract you while you’re driving?
column10: Except for emergencies, it’s illegal to use a hand-held mobile phone while you're driving. Even using a hands-free kit can severely distract your attention.
column11:
5/8/2015:  5 August 2015 changed to Mark one answer
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: You're driving your car. When may you use a hand-held mobile phone?
column8: When you're driving at less than 30 mph
column9: When your car has automatic transmission
column10: It's illegal to use a hand-held mobile phone while you're driving, except in a genuine emergency. Even using a hands-free kit can distract your attention. Park in a safe and convenient place before receiving or making a call or using text messaging. Then you'll also be free to take notes or refer to papers.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: You're driving on a wet road. What should you do if you have to stop your vehicle in an emergency?
column6: Apply the parking brake and footbrake together
column7: Keep both hands on the steering wheel
column10: As you drive, look well ahead and all around so that you’re ready for any hazards that might develop. If you have to stop in an emergency, react as soon as you can while keeping control of the vehicle. Keep both hands on the steering wheel so you can control the vehicle's direction of travel.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: What should you do when you move off from behind a parked car?
column6: Give a signal after moving off
column10: Before moving off, you should use both the interior and exterior mirrors to check that the road is clear. Look around to check the blind spots and, if necessary, give a signal to warn other road users of your intentions. Also look well ahead as you'll have to steer out into the road to pass the parked car.
column11:
5/8/2015:  5 August 2015 changed to Mark one answer
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: You're travelling along this road. How should you pass the cyclist?
column6: Sound your horn as you pass
column7: Keep close to them as you pass
column8: Leave them plenty of room as you pass
column9: Change down one gear before you pass
column10: Allow the cyclist plenty of room in case they wobble or swerve around a pothole or raised drain. Look well ahead before you start to overtake, because you'll need to cross the hazard line. Look for entrances where vehicles could be waiting to pull out.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: When do windscreen pillars cause a serious obstruction to your view?
column6: When you're driving on a motorway
column7: When you're driving on a dual carriageway
column8: When you're approaching a one-way street
column9: When you're approaching bends and junctions
column10: Windscreen pillars can obstruct your view, particularly at bends and junctions. Look out for other road users – especially cyclists, motorcyclists and pedestrians who can easily be overlooked.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: What should you do if you cannot see clearly behind when you're reversing?
column6: Open the window to look behind
column7: Open the door to look behind
column10: If you want to turn your car around, try to find a place where you have good all-round vision. If this is not possible, and you’re unable to see clearly, then get someone to guide you.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contractions

column4: What does the term ‘blind spot’ mean?
column6: An area covered by your right-hand mirror
column7: An area not covered by your headlights
column8: An area covered by your left-hand mirror
column9: An area not visible to the driver
column10: Modern vehicles provide the driver with a good view of both the road ahead and behind using well-positioned mirrors. However, the mirrors cannot see every angle of the scene behind and to the sides of the vehicle. It’s essential that you know when and how to check the vehicle's blind spots, so that you’re aware of any hidden hazards.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
24/2/2017:  Re-written following comments from ColinThornicroft who was unhappy with the old question
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contraction

column4: What's likely to happen if you use a hands-free phone while you're driving?
column10: Talking to someone while you're driving can distract you and, unlike when someone is in the car with you, the person on the other end of a mobile phone is unable to see the traffic situations you're dealing with. They will not stop speaking to you even if you're approaching a hazardous situation. You need to concentrate on your driving at all times.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contraction

column4: You're turning right onto a dual carriageway. What should you do before emerging?
column6: Stop, apply the parking brake and then select a low gear
column7: Position your vehicle well to the left of the side road
column8: Check that the central reservation is wide enough for your vehicle
column9: Make sure that you leave enough room for a vehicle behind
column10: Before emerging right onto a dual carriageway, make sure that the central reservation is deep enough to protect your vehicle. If it’s not, you should treat the dual carriageway as one road and check that it’s clear in both directions before pulling out. Neglecting to do this could place part or all of your vehicle in the path of approaching traffic and cause a collision.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contraction

column4: You're waiting to emerge from a junction. The windscreen pillar is restricting your view. What should you be particularly aware of?
column10: Windscreen pillars can completely block your view of pedestrians, motorcyclists and cyclists. You should make a particular effort to look for these road users; do not just rely on a quick glance.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contraction

column4: How can you make sure that a satellite navigation (sat nav) system does not distract you when you're driving?
column6: Turn it off while you're driving in built-up areas
column7: Choose a voice that you find calming
column8: Only set the destination when you're lost
column9: Set it before starting your journey
column10: Sat navs can be useful when driving on unfamiliar routes. However, they can also distract you and cause you to lose control if you look at or adjust them while you're driving. Set the sat nav before starting your journey, or pull up in a safe place before making any changes to it.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contraction

column4: What must you do when the amber light is flashing at a pelican crossing?
column6: Stop and wait for the green light
column7: Stop and wait for the red light
column8: Give way to pedestrians waiting to cross
column9: Give way to pedestrians already on the crossing
column10: Pelican crossings are signal-controlled crossings operated by pedestrians. Push-button controls change the signals. Pelican crossings have no red-and-amber stage before green; instead, they have a flashing amber light. This means you must give way to pedestrians who are on the crossing but if the crossing is clear you can continue.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: Why should you never wave people across at pedestrian crossings?
column8: It's safer for you to carry on
column9: They may not be ready to cross
column10: If people are waiting to use a pedestrian crossing, slow down and be prepared to stop. Do not wave them across the road, because another driver may not have seen them, may not have seen your signal, and may not be able to stop safely.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contraction

column4: Why is it dangerous to travel too close to the vehicle ahead?
column8: Your view of the road ahead will be restricted
column9: Your sat nav will be confused
column10: ‘Tailgating’ is the term used when a driver or rider follows the vehicle in front too closely. It's dangerous because it restricts your view of the road ahead and leaves no safety margin if the vehicle in front needs to slow down or stop suddenly. Tailgating is often the underlying cause of rear-end collisions or multiple pile-ups.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
20/3/2020:  Stem changed to make it work for both car and motorcycle tests.

column4: What will happen if you follow this vehicle too closely?
column7: Your fuel consumption will be increased
column9: Your view ahead will be reduced
column10: Staying back will increase your view of the road ahead. This will help you to see any hazards that might occur and give you more time to react.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: What's the minimum time gap you should leave when following a vehicle on a wet road?
column10: Water will reduce your tyres' grip on the road. The safe separation gap of at least two seconds in dry conditions should be doubled, to at least four seconds, in wet weather.
column11: 29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility

column4: You're being overtaken by a long, heavily laden lorry. What should you do if it's taking a long time for it to overtake?
column10: A long lorry with a heavy load will need more time to pass you than a car, especially on an uphill stretch of road. Slow down and allow the lorry to pass.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: Which vehicle will use a blue flashing beacon?
column10: Emergency vehicles use blue flashing lights. If you see or hear one, move out of its way as soon as it's safe and legal to do so.
column11: 7/8/2015:  Amended made during the global change to 'Mark one answer'

column4: What should you do if you're being followed by an ambulance showing flashing blue lights?
column6: Pull over as soon as it's safe to do so
column7: Accelerate hard to get away from it
column9: Brake harshly and stop well out into the road
column10: Pull over in a place where the ambulance can pass safely. Check that there are no bollards or obstructions in the road that will prevent it from passing.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: What type of emergency vehicle is fitted with a green flashing beacon?
column10: A green flashing beacon on a vehicle means the driver or passenger is a doctor on an emergency call. Give way to them if it's safe to do so. Be aware that the vehicle may be travelling quickly or may stop in a hurry.

column4: Who should obey diamond-shaped traffic signs?
column10: These signs apply only to tram drivers, but you should know their meaning so that you're aware of the priorities and are able to anticipate the actions of the driver.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
23/11/2023:  Updates to cross references after new KYTS

column4: On a road where trams operate, which vehicles will be most at risk from the tram rails?
column10: The narrow wheels of a bicycle can become stuck in the tram rails, causing the cyclist to stop suddenly, wobble or even lose balance altogether. The tramlines are also slippery, which could cause a cyclist to slide or fall off.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: You're in a one-way street and want to turn right. Where should you position your vehicle when there are two lanes?
column8: In either lane, depending on the traffic
column9: Just left of the centre line
column10: When you’re in a one-way street and want to turn right, you should take up a position in the right-hand lane. This will allow other road users, not wishing to turn, to pass on the left. Indicate your intention and take up the correct position in good time.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: You wish to turn right ahead. Why should you take up the correct position in good time?
column6: To allow other drivers to pull out in front of you
column7: To give a better view into the road that you're joining
column8: To help other road users know what you intend to do
column9: To allow drivers to pass you on the right
column10: If you wish to turn right into a side road, take up your position in good time. Move to the centre of the road when it's safe to do so. This will allow vehicles to pass you on the left. Early planning will show other traffic what you intend to do.
column11: 09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style

column4: Which type of crossing allows cyclists to ride across with pedestrians?
column10: A toucan crossing is designed to allow pedestrians and cyclists to cross at the same time. Look out for cyclists approaching the crossing at speed.
column11:
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
11/8/2020:  Changed for clarity since introduction of parallel crossings
23/11/2023:  Updates to cross references after new KYTS

column4: You're travelling at the legal speed limit. What should you do if the vehicle behind approaches quickly, flashing its headlights?
column6: Accelerate to make a gap behind you
column7: Touch the brakes sharply to show your brake lights
column8: Maintain your speed to prevent the vehicle from overtaking
column10: Do not enforce the speed limit by blocking another vehicle’s progress. This will only cause frustration. Allow the other vehicle to pass when you can do so safely.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: When should you flash your headlights at other road users?
column6: When showing that you're giving way
column7: When showing that you're about to turn
column8: When telling them that you have right of way
column9: When letting them know that you're there
column10: You should only flash your headlights to warn others of your presence. Do not use them to greet others, show impatience or give priority to other road users, because they could misunderstand your signal.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contraction

column4: You're approaching an unmarked crossroads. How should you deal with the junction?
column6: Accelerate and keep to the middle
column7: Slow down and keep to the right
column8: Accelerate and look to the left
column9: Slow down and look both ways
column10: Be cautious, especially when your view is restricted by hedges, bushes, walls, large vehicles, etc. In the summer months, these junctions can become more difficult to deal with, because growing foliage may further obscure your view.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: The conditions are good and dry. When should you use the 'two-second rule'?
column6: Before restarting the engine after it has stalled
column7: When checking your gap from the vehicle in front
column8: Before using the 'Mirrors - Signal - Manoeuvre' routine
column9: When traffic lights change to green
column10: In good conditions, the 'two-second rule' can be used to check the distance between your vehicle and the one in front. This technique works on roads carrying faster traffic. Choose a fixed object, such as a bridge, sign or tree. When the vehicle ahead passes this object, say to yourself 'Only a fool breaks the two-second rule.' If you reach the object before you finish saying this, you're too close.
column11: 29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility

column4: Which colour follows the green signal at a puffin crossing?
column10: Puffin crossings have infra-red sensors that detect when pedestrians are crossing and hold the red traffic signal until the crossing is clear. The use of a sensor means there's no flashing amber phase as there is with a pelican crossing.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: You're in a line of traffic. What action should you take if the driver behind is following very closely?
column6: Ignore the driver behind and continue to travel within the speed limit
column7: Slow down, gradually increasing the gap between you and the vehicle in front
column8: Signal left and wave the driver behind to come past
column9: Move over to a position just left of the centre line of the road
column10: If the driver behind is following too closely, there’s a danger they’ll collide with the back of your vehicle if you stop suddenly. You can reduce this risk by slowing down and increasing the safety margin in front of you. This reduces the chance that you’ll have to stop suddenly and allows you to spread your braking over a greater distance. This is an example of defensive driving.
column11:
4/8/2015:  Expl text amended to try and give improved clarity as this seems to be a misunderstood concept.
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
18/7/2016:  Expl text - 'car' changed to 'vehicle' as its a shared car or motorcycle question.
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: You’re travelling along a single-track road. There’s a passing place on your right. What should you do if you see a vehicle coming towards you?
column10: When you meet oncoming vehicles on a single-track road, you should allow them to pass. You should pull into a passing place on your left or wait opposite a passing place on your right. Do not move onto the verge as there may be hidden hazards.

column4: You're driving on a clear night. Which lights should you use if the national speed limit applies and there's a steady stream of oncoming traffic?
column10: Use the full-beam headlights only when you can be sure that you will not dazzle other road users.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contraction

column4: You're driving behind a heavy goods vehicle. What should you do if it signals left but steers to the right?
column6: Slow down and let the vehicle turn
column7: Drive on, keeping to the left
column8: Overtake on the right of it
column9: Hold your speed and sound your horn
column10: Large, long vehicles need extra room when making turns at junctions. They may move out to the right in order to make a left turn. Keep well back and do not attempt to pass them on their left.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
4/12/2023:  Stem changed for consistent use of term ‘heavy goods vehicle’.
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contraction

column4: You're driving along this road. What should you do if the red car cuts in close in front of you?
column6: Accelerate to get closer to the red car
column7: Give a long blast on the horn
column8: Drop back to leave the correct separation distance
column10: There are times when other drivers make incorrect or ill-judged decisions. Be tolerant and try not to retaliate or react aggressively. Always consider the safety of other road users, your passengers and yourself.
column11:
09/02/2016:  AB and BB Items edited by TSO for style
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review

column4: You're waiting in a traffic queue at night. How can you avoid dazzling drivers behind you?
column6: Use the parking brake and release the footbrake
column7: Keep your foot on the footbrake
column8: Balance the clutch with the accelerator
column9: Use the parking brake and footbrake together
column10: In queuing traffic, your brake lights can dazzle drivers behind you. If you apply your parking brake, you can take your foot off the footbrake. This will turn off the brake lights so that they do not dazzle the driver behind you.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility
25/7/2019:  Change following 2019 review
24/9/2024:  Remove negative contraction

column4: You're driving in traffic at the speed limit for the road. What should you do if the driver behind is trying to overtake?
column6: Move closer to the car ahead, so the driver behind has no room to overtake
column7: Wave the driver behind to overtake when it's safe
column8: Keep a steady course and allow the driver behind to overtake
column9: Accelerate to get away from the driver behind
column10: Keep a steady course to give the driver behind an opportunity to overtake safely. If necessary, slow down. Reacting incorrectly to another driver's impatience can lead to danger.
column11: 29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility

column4: What does it mean if the signs at a bus lane show no times of operation?
column6: The lane is not in operation
column7: The lane is only in operation at peak times

You should not coast, especially when approaching hazards such as junctions or bends and when travelling downhill.

column4: You're driving on a motorway and have to slow down suddenly due to a hazard ahead. How can you warn drivers behind of the hazard?

column4: Your car gets a puncture while you're driving on the motorway. What should you do when you've stopped on the hard shoulder?
column7: Use an emergency telephone and call for help
column8: Try to wave down another vehicle for help
column9: Only change the wheel if you have a passenger to help you

Instead, walk to an emergency telephone on your side of the road and phone for help. While waiting for help to arrive, stay by your car, keeping well away from the carriageway and hard shoulder.

column6: Carefully reverse along the hard shoulder
column7: Carry on to the next exit
column8: Carefully reverse in the left-hand lane
column9: Make a U-turn at the next gap in the central reservation
column10: It's illegal to reverse, cross the central reservation or drive against the traffic flow on a motorway. If you miss your exit, carry on until you reach the next one. Ask yourself why you missed your exit – if you think that your concentration is fading, take a break before continuing your journey.

column7: Stop the traffic behind and ask for help

column9: Stand behind your vehicle to warn others
column10: If you cannot get your vehicle onto the hard shoulder, use your hazard warning lights to warn others. Leave your vehicle only when you can safely get clear of the carriageway. Do not try to repair the vehicle or attempt to place any warning device on the carriageway.

column8: The road surface will wear down the tyres faster
column9: Continuous high speeds increase the risk of your vehicle breaking down
column10: Before you start your journey, make sure that your vehicle can cope with the demands of high-speed driving. You should check a number of things; the main ones being fuel, oil, water and tyres. You also need to plan rest stops if you’re making a long journey.

column8: Traffic ahead is slowing or stopping suddenly
column9: There's a police speed check ahead

column4: You're driving on the motorway. Which lane should you get into well before you reach your exit?
column10: You’ll see the first advance direction sign one mile from a motorway exit. If you’re travelling at 60 mph in the right-hand lane, you’ll only have about 50 seconds before you reach the countdown markers. There'll be another sign at the half-mile point. Do not cut across lanes of traffic at the last moment – move to the left-hand lane in good time.

column9: They cannot drive with more than one passenger
column10: You will not be able to drive unaccompanied until you've passed your practical driving test. If you’ve not driven on the motorway while you were learning, ask your instructor to take you for a lesson on the motorway when you've passed your test. Alternatively, you could take part in the Pass Plus scheme. This has been created for new drivers and includes motorway driving. Ask your instructor for details.

column7: Phone a friend and ask them to come and collect you
column8: Wait in the car for the emergency services to arrive
column9: Check your location from the nearest marker posts beside the hard shoulder
column10: You should use an emergency telephone when you break down on the motorway; only use your mobile if this is not possible. The emergency services need to know your exact location so they can reach you as quickly as possible. Look for a number on the nearest marker post beside the hard shoulder. Give this number when you call the emergency services.

Be aware that the hard shoulder may be used for traffic and the road ahead could be obstructed by slow-moving or broken-down vehicles.

column10: Make sure that you know the speed limit for the road that you're on. The speed limit on a dual carriageway or motorway is 70 mph for cars and motorcycles, unless signs indicate otherwise. The speed limits for different types of vehicle are listed in The Highway Code.

column4: There are no speed-limit signs on the road. In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland how is a 30 mph limit generally indicated?
column9: By double or single yellow lines
column10:
In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland, there's a 30 mph speed limit where there are street lights unless signs show another limit. 
In Wales street lights indicate the limit is 20 mph unless signs show otherwise.

column4: In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland what will the speed limit usually be where you can see street lights but no speed-limit signs?
column10:
In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland the presence of street lights generally indicates that there's a 30 mph speed limit, unless signs tell you otherwise.
In Wales street lights indicate a 20 mph limit unless signs show otherwise.
column11:
29/01/2016:  Continuation question re-written for accessibility

column6: Follow another vehicle as it overtakes the tractor
column7: Sound your horn to make the tractor driver pull over
column8: Speed past, flashing your lights at oncoming traffic
column9: Stay behind it if you're in any doubt
column10: Following a tractor can be frustrating, but never overtake if you’re unsure whether it’s safe. Ask yourself: 'Can I see far enough down the road to make sure that I can complete the manoeuvre safely?' It's better to be delayed for a minute or two than to take a chance that may cause a collision.

column4: When may you stop on a clearway?
column10: Clearways are in place so that traffic can flow without the obstruction of parked vehicles. Just one parked vehicle can cause an obstruction for all other traffic. You must not stop where a clearway is in force, not even to pick up or set down passengers.

column4: You're looking for somewhere to park at night. When may you park on the right-hand side of the road?

column7: When you have your sidelights on
column8: When you're more than 10 metres (32 feet) from a junction
column10: Red rear reflectors show up when headlights shine on them. These are useful when you're parked at night, but they'll only reflect if you park in the same direction as the traffic flow. Normally you should park on the left, but in a one-way street you may also park on the right-hand side of the road.

column10:
You should normally use the left-hand lane on any dual carriageway unless you're overtaking or turning right. 
When overtaking on a dual carriageway, look for vehicles ahead that are turning right. They may be slowing or stopped. You need to see them in good time so that you can take appropriate action.

column7: Force your way into the lane you need
column8: Stop until the area has cleared
column9: Use arm signals to help you change lane
column10: There are times when road markings are obscured by queuing traffic, or you're unsure which lane to use. If, at the last moment, you find you're in the wrong lane, do not cut across or bully other drivers to let you in. Follow the lane you’re in and find somewhere safe to turn around and rejoin your route.

column9: Signal left when you're approaching the roundabout

column9: Ignore them as they're still on the pavement

column8: You'll have more time to turn
column9: You'll be able to turn without stopping

This allows you a clear view of approaching traffic and is called 'turning offside to offside'. However, some junctions, usually controlled by traffic-light filters - are marked for vehicles to turn nearside to nearside.

• vehicles pulling out, especially bicycles and motorcycles
• pedestrians, especially children, who may run out from between cars
• drivers opening their doors.

column8: So that you can switch to main beam quickly

column4: You're turning right onto a dual carriageway. What should you do if the central reservation is too narrow to contain your vehicle?

column10: To go straight ahead at a roundabout, you should normally approach in the left-hand lane, but check the road markings. column4: You’ve just passed your driving test. What’s the maximum authorised mass (MAM) of any trailer that you can tow?
column10:
When you pass your driving test, you're allowed to tow a trailer up to 3,500 kg MAM without taking an extra test. 
If you want to tow a heavier trailer, you'll have to pass either a CE or DE category test, dependent on the towing vehicle.

column4: What should you do before you tow a trailer for the first time?
column6: Ask DVLA to update your licence
column7: Fit P plates to your trailer
column10: You need to know how to tow a trailer safely. This includes hitching the trailer to your vehicle, checking the trailer for defects, reversing with a trailer and how to deal with any problems. There are accredited trainers who can teach you these skills. Professional training will also give you confidence in your ability to tow a trailer safely.

column4: You're going to tow a trailer that’s wider than your car. What must you fit to your car before you start towing it?
column10:
You must fit exterior towing mirrors to your vehicle if
•  your vehicle is narrower than your trailer or load
•  your trailer or load obstructs the view behind you.

column7: Grease the tow ball and hitch

column9: Make sure you can see the trailer in the mirrors
column10: If a tow hitch fails, the trailer must stay connected to the towing vehicle. This is achieved by using a secondary coupling device, such as a safety chain.

column4: What’s the minimum depth of tread on the tyres of a trailer?
column10: Your car or small van must have a minimum tread depth of 1.6 mm across the centre of the tread and around the entire circumference. This also applies to the tyres on your trailer.

column4: You’re about to start a journey towing a trailer. What should you do if you notice that a light on your trailer is not working?
column6: Continue with your journey because the lights on your car are working
column7: Disconnect the trailer electrical coupling before continuing with your journey
column8: Repair the fault before continuing with your journey
column9: Book the trailer in for repair before continuing with your journey
column10:
You must make sure that your vehicle and trailer are roadworthy. Check that your tyres are legal, and the brakes and lights are working properly. 
If any of these things are not working, you must not drive or tow your trailer until the fault is repaired.

column4: What does it mean if your trailer has a maximum authorised mass (MAM) of 3,500 kg?
column6: Your trailer can carry a load of 3,500 kg
column8: Your trailer and towing vehicle combined cannot weigh more than 3,500 kg
column9: Your trailer and load combined cannot weigh more than 3,500 kg
column10: The MAM of the trailer is stamped on the plate fitted to the chassis. It is the maximum weight of the trailer and load that the manufacturer has designed it to carry. Do not load your trailer so that it exceeds this maximum weight.

column4: What should you do if your trailer starts to swerve or snake?
column10: If your trailer starts to swerve or snake, reduce speed gently to regain control. Do not accelerate or brake harshly.

column4: How should you load your trailer?
column6: Put heavy items at the front
column7: Put heavy items at the back
column8: Put heavy items over the axle(s)
column9: Put heavy items in the corners
column10: When loading your trailer, you should spread the weight evenly with heavy items over the axle(s). This should reduce the risk of it swerving or snaking.
